Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
G-200 I-MISC
Study O
Design O
and O
Further O
Results O
The O
Phase O
2 O
trial O
was O
designed O
to O
enroll O
approximately O
30 O
patients O
with O
recurrent O
high-grade O
GBM I-MISC
" " O
the O
deadliest O
form O
of O
brain O
cancer O
. O

Patients O
underwent O
surgery O
to O
remove O
> O
90 O
% O
of O
their O
tumors O
( O
also O
referred O
to O
as O
gross O
total O
resection O
) O
" " O
which O
were O
then O
used O
to O
manufacture O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
G-200 I-MISC
" " O
a O
patient-specific O
heat O
shock O
protein O
based O
therapeutic O
vaccine O
. O

Eligible O
patients O
were O
treated O
after O
surgery O
with O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
G-200 I-MISC
once O
weekly O
for O
four O
weeks O
" " O
followed O
by O
biweekly O
injections O
until O
vaccine O
depletion O
or O
disease O
progression O
. O

A O
total O
of O
33 O
patients O
were O
enrolled O
( O
ITT O
population O
) O
and O
all O
received O
at O
least O
one O
dose O
of O
vaccine O
; O
30 O
of O
the O
33 O
patients O
were O
considered O
evaluable O
per-protocol O
as O
they O
received O
4 O
doses O
of O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
G-200 I-MISC
. O

The O
median O
patient O
age O
was O
53 O
years O
and O
all O
had O
an O
original O
diagnosis O
of O
GBM I-MISC
" " O
which O
tends O
to O
carry O
a O
poor O
prognosis O
. O

Results O
in O
the O
ITT O
population O
were O
similar O
to O
those O
reported O
on O
in O
the O
evaluable O
group O
( O
91 O
% O
survival O
rate O
at O
26 O
weeks O
; O
median O
survival O
rate O
of O
42.6 O
weeks O
) O
. O

Results O
from O
pre-defined O
exploratory O
analyses O
of O
disease O
progression O
showed O
a O
median O
progression O
free O
survival O
( O
PFS O
) O
of O
approximately O
5 O
months O
( O
20 O
weeks O
) O
in O
the O
evaluable O
population O
" " O
which O
were O
also O
similar O
in O
the O
ITT O
population O
( O
PFS O
of O
17.1 O
weeks O
) O
. O

800.642.1687 O
( O
domestic O
) O
or O
706.645.9291 O
( O
international O
) O
" " O
and O
the O
access O
code O
is O
67451717 O
. O

About O
Glioblastoma I-MISC
Multiforme I-MISC
( O
GBM I-MISC
) O
The O
incidence O
rates O
of O
primary O
malignant O
brain O
and O
central O
nervous O
system O
( O
CNS O
) O
cancers O
have O
increased O
over O
the O
last O
three O
decades O
. O

The O
American I-ORG
Cancer I-ORG
Society I-ORG
estimates O
that O
more O
than O
"22,000" O
malignant O
tumors O
of O
the O
brain O
or O
spinal O
cord O
were O
diagnosed O
during O
2010 O
in O
the O
US I-LOC
and O
that O
more O
than O
"13,000" O
people O
would O
die O
from O
these O
tumors O
. O

Glioblastoma I-MISC
is O
the O
most O
common O
primary O
malignant O
brain O
tumor O
and O
accounts O
for O
the O
majority O
of O
diagnoses O
and O
has O
been O
associated O
with O
a O
particularly O
poor O
prognosis O
" " O
with O
survival O
rates O
at O
1 O
and O
5 O
years O
equaling O
33.7 O
% O
and O
4.5 O
% O
" " O
respectively O
. O

The O
current O
standard O
of O
care O
for O
patients O
with O
newly O
diagnosed O
glioblastoma I-MISC
is O
surgical O
resection O
followed O
by O
fractionated O
external O
beam O
radiotherapy O
and O
systemic O
temozolomide I-MISC
resulting O
in O
a O
median O
overall O
survival O
( O
OS O
) O
of O
14.6 O
months O
based O
on O
data O
from O
a O
randomized O
Phase O
III O
trial O
. O

Although O
this O
treatment O
can O
prolong O
survival O
" " O
it O
is O
not O
curative O
and O
the O
vast O
majority O
of O
patients O
with O
glioblastoma O
experience O
recurrent O
disease O
" " O
with O
a O
median O
time O
to O
recurrence O
of O
7 O
months O
. O

Currently O
" " O
there O
is O
no O
standard O
treatment O
for O
patients O
with O
recurrent O
glioblastoma I-MISC
" " O
although O
additional O
surgery O
" " O
chemotherapy O
( O
i.e. O
" " O
CCNU I-MISC
" " O
temozolomide I-MISC
) O
" " O
bevacizumab I-MISC
" " O
and O
radiotherapy O
are O
used O
. O

About O
the O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
of O
Cancer O
Vaccines O
The O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
of O
vaccines O
are O
patient-specific O
therapeutic O
cancer O
vaccine O
candidates O
. O

Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
vaccines O
contain O
the O
heat O
shock O
protein O
" " O
gp96 I-MISC
" " O
and O
associated O
peptides O
that O
are O
purified O
from O
patient O
tumor O
tissue O
. O

Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
vaccines O
are O
designed O
to O
target O
only O
cancerous O
cells O
 O
not O
healthy O
normal O
cells O
. O

As O
a O
result O
" " O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
vaccines O
are O
designed O
to O
limit O
the O
toxicities O
associated O
with O
traditional O
broad-acting O
cancer O
treatments O
. O

In O
addition O
to O
the O
recurrent O
GBM I-MISC
study O
reported O
above O
" " O
a O
Phase O
2 O
trial O
testing O
Prophage I-MISC
Series I-MISC
G-100 I-MISC
in O
newly O
diagnosed O
GBM I-MISC
is O
on-going O
and O
actively O
enrolling O
patients O
. O

This O
trial O
is O
also O
being O
sponsored O
by O
Dr. O
Andrew I-PER
Parsa I-PER
of O
UCSF I-ORG
and O
primarily O
supported O
with O
funding O
from O
the O
American I-ORG
Brain I-ORG
Tumor I-ORG
Association I-ORG
" " O
Accelerated I-ORG
Brain I-ORG
Cancer I-ORG
Cure I-ORG
" " O
National I-ORG
Brain I-ORG
Tumor I-ORG
Society I-ORG
" " O
and O
National I-GOVERNMENT
Cancer I-GOVERNMENT
Institute I-GOVERNMENT
Special I-GOVERNMENT
Programs I-GOVERNMENT
of I-GOVERNMENT
Research I-GOVERNMENT

. O

The O
glioma I-MISC

in O

" " O
2010 O
and O

holding O
a O

of O
the O

This O
Information O
Statement O
contains O
a O
brief O

of O
the O

of O
the O
actions O
approved O
by O
the O
Board O
and O
the O

of O
the O

of O
the O
outstanding O
voting O

stock O
of O
the O
Company O
. O

The O
Board O
approved O
a O
resolution O
to O
effect O
a O
1-for-85 O
reverse O
stock O
split O
. O

Under O
this O
reverse O
stock O
split O
each O
85 O
shares O
of O
our O
Common O
Stock O
will O
be O
converted O
automatically O
into O
1 O
share O
of O
Common O
Stock O
. O

To O
avoid O
the O
issuance O
of O
fractional O
shares O
of O
Company O
Common O
Stock O
" " O
the O
Company O
will O
issue O
an O
additional O
share O
to O
all O
holders O
of O
fractional O
shares O
. O

The O
Company O
anticipates O
that O
the O
effective O
date O
of O
the O
reverse O
stock O
split O
will O
be O
April O
5 O
" " O
2010 O
. O

PLEASE O
NOTE O
THAT O
THE O
REVERSE O
STOCK O
SPLIT O
WILL O
NOT O
CHANGE O
YOUR O
PROPORTIONATE O
EQUITY O
INTERESTS O
IN O
THE O
COMPANY O
" " O
EXCEPT O
AS O
MAY O
RESULT O
FROM O
THE O
ISSUANCE O
OR O
CANCELLATION O
OF O
SHARES O
PURSUANT O
TO O
THE O
FRACTIONAL O
SHARES O
. O

PLEASE O
NOTE O
THAT O
THE O
REVERSE O
SPLIT O
WILL O
HAVE O
THE O
EFFECT O
OF O
SUBSTANTIALLY O
INCREASING O
THE O
NUMBER O
OF O
SHARES O
THE O
COMPANY O
WILL O
BE O
ABLE O
TO O
ISSUE O
TO O
NEW O
OR O
EXISTING O
SHAREHOLDERS O
BECAUSE O
THE O
NUMBER O
OF O
AUTHORIZED O
SHARES O
AND O
THE O
PAR O
VALUE O
PER O
SHARE O
OF O
COMMON O
STOCK O
WILL O
REMAIN O
THE O
SAME O
WHILE O
THE O
NUMBER O
OF O
SHARES O
ISSUED O
AND O
OUTSTANDING O
WILL O
BE O
REDUCED O
TEN-FOLD O
. O

The O
Board O
of O
Directors O
believe O
that O
" " O
among O
other O
reasons O
" " O
the O
number O
of O
outstanding O
shares O
of O
our O
Common O
Stock O
have O
contributed O
to O
a O
lack O
of O
investor O
interest O
in O
the O
Company O
and O
has O
made O
it O
difficult O
to O
attract O
new O
investors O
and O
potential O
business O
candidates O
. O

The O
Board O
of O
Directors O
has O
proposed O
the O
Reverse O
Stock O
Split O
as O
one O
method O
to O
attract O
business O
opportunities O
in O
the O
Company O
. O

When O
a O
company O
engages O
in O
a O
reverse O
stock O
split O
" " O
it O
substitutes O
one O
share O
of O
stock O
for O
a O
predetermined O
amount O
of O
shares O
of O
stock O
. O

It O
does O
not O
increase O
the O
market O
capitalization O
of O
the O
company O
. O

An O
example O
of O
a O
reverse O
split O
is O
the O
following O
. O

A O
company O
has O
"10,000,000" O
shares O
of O
common O
stock O
outstanding O
. O

Assume O
the O
market O
price O
is O
$ O
.01 O
per O
share O
. O

Assume O
that O
the O
company O
declares O
a O
1 O
for O
5 O
reverse O
stock O
split O
. O

After O
the O
reverse O
split O
" " O
that O
company O
will O
have O
1/5 O
as O
many O
shares O
outstanding O
or O
"2,000,000" O
shares O
outstanding O
. O

The O
stock O
will O
have O
a O
market O
price O
of O
$ O
0.05 O
. O

If O
an O
individual O
investor O
owned O
"10,000" O
shares O
of O
that O
company O
before O
the O
split O
at O
$ O
.01 O
per O
share O
" " O
he O
will O
own O
"2,000" O
shares O
at O
$ O
.05 O
after O
the O
split O
. O

In O
either O
case O
" " O
his O
stock O
will O
be O
worth O
$ O
100 O
. O

He O
is O
no O
better O
off O
before O
or O
after O
. O

Except O
that O
such O
company O
hopes O
that O
the O
higher O
stock O
price O
will O
make O
that O
company O
look O
better O
and O
thus O
the O
company O
will O
be O
a O
more O
attractive O
merger O
target O
for O
potential O
business O
. O

There O
is O
no O
assurance O
that O
that O
company O
's O
stock O
will O
rise O
in O
price O
after O
a O
reverse O
split O
or O
that O
a O
suitable O
merger O
candidate O
will O
emerge O
. O

We O
believe O
that O
the O
reverse O
stock O
split O
may O
improve O
the O
price O
level O
of O
our O
Common O
Stock O
and O
that O
the O
higher O
share O
price O
could O
help O
generate O
interest O
in O
the O
Company O
among O
investors O
and O
other O
business O
opportunities O
. O

However O
" " O
the O
effect O
of O
the O
reverse O
split O
upon O
the O
market O
price O
for O
our O
Common O
Stock O
can O
not O
be O
predicted O
" " O
and O
the O
history O
of O
similar O
stock O
split O
combinations O
for O
companies O
in O
like O
circumstances O
is O
varied O
. O

There O
can O
be O
no O
assurance O
that O
the O
market O
price O
per O
share O
of O
our O
Common O
Stock O
after O
the O
reverse O
split O
will O
rise O
in O
proportion O
to O
the O
reduction O
in O
the O
number O
of O
shares O
of O
Common O
Stock O
outstanding O
resulting O
from O
the O
reverse O
split O
. O

The O
market O
price O
of O
our O
Common O
Stock O
may O
also O
be O
based O
on O
our O
performance O
and O
other O
factors O
" " O
some O
of O
which O
may O
be O
unrelated O
to O
the O
number O
of O
shares O
outstanding O
. O

The O
reverse O
split O
will O
affect O
all O
of O
our O
stockholders O
uniformly O
and O
will O
not O
affect O
any O
stockholder O
's O
percentage O
ownership O
interests O
in O
the O
Company O
or O
proportionate O
voting O
power O
" " O
except O
to O
the O
extent O
that O
the O
reverse O
split O
results O
in O
any O
of O
our O
stockholders O
owning O
a O
fractional O
share O
. O

All O
stockholders O
holding O
a O
fractional O
share O
shall O
be O
issued O
an O
additional O
share O
. O

The O
principal O
effect O
of O
the O
reverse O
split O
will O
be O
that O
the O
number O
of O
shares O
of O
Common O
Stock O
issued O
and O
outstanding O
will O
be O
reduced O
from O
"744,640,134" O
shares O
as O
of O
March O
5 O
" " O
2010 O
to O
approximately O
"8,760,472" O
shares O

BEAUTY I-ORG
BRANDS I-ORG
GROUP I-ORG
" " I-ORG
INC. I-ORG
( O
`` O
We O
'' O
" " O
`` O
Us O
'' O
or O
the O
`` O
Company O
'' O
) O
is O
a O
Florida I-LOC
corporation O
and O
was O
incorporated O
in O
1968 O
as O
“ O
Chemair I-ORG
Corporation I-ORG
of I-ORG
America. I-ORG
” O
In O
February O
1983 O
" " O
the O
Company O
changed O
its O
name O
to O
Beauty I-ORG
Brands I-ORG
Group I-ORG
" " I-ORG
Inc. I-ORG
. O

The O
Company O
is O
now O
considering O
business O
opportunities O
for O
merger O
or O
acquisition O
that O
might O
create O
value O
for O
its O
shareholders O
. O

We O
have O
no O
day-to-day O
operations O
. O

Our O
officers O
and O
directors O
devote O
limited O
time O
and O
attention O
to O
the O
affairs O
of O
the O
Company O
. O

Management O
has O
adopted O
a O
conservative O
policy O
of O
seeking O
opportunities O
that O
it O
considers O
to O
be O
of O
exceptional O
quality O
. O

Therefore O
" " O
we O
may O
have O
to O
wait O
some O
time O
before O
consummating O
a O
suitable O
transaction O
. O

Management O
recognizes O
that O
the O
higher O
the O
standards O
it O
imposes O
upon O
us O
" " O
the O
greater O
may O
be O
its O
competitive O
disadvantage O
when O
vying O
with O
other O
acquiring O
interests O
or O
entities O
. O

The O
Company O
does O
not O
intend O
to O
restrict O
its O
consideration O
to O
any O
particular O
business O
or O
industry O
segment O
. O

Due O
to O
our O
lack O
of O
financial O
resources O
" " O
the O
scope O
and O
number O
of O
suitable O
business O
ventures O
is O
limited O
. O

We O
are O
therefore O
most O
likely O
to O
participate O
in O
a O
single O
business O
venture O
. O

Accordingly O
" " O
the O
Company O
may O
not O
be O
able O
to O
diversify O
and O
may O
be O
limited O
to O
one O
merger O
or O
acquisition O
. O

The O
lack O
of O
diversification O
would O
prevent O
us O
from O
offsetting O
losses O
from O
one O
business O
opportunity O
against O
profits O
from O
another O
. O

The O
decision O
to O
participate O
in O
a O
specific O
business O
opportunity O
will O
be O
made O
upon O
management O
’ O
s O
analysis O
of O
the O
quality O
of O
the O
opportunity O
’ O
s O
management O
and O
personnel O
" " O
the O
anticipated O
acceptability O
of O
products O
or O
marketing O
concepts O
" " O
the O
merit O
of O
technological O
changes O
and O
numerous O
other O
factors O
which O
are O
difficult O
" " O
if O
not O
impossible O
" " O
to O
analyze O
through O
the O
application O
of O
any O
objective O
criteria O
. O

Further O
" " O
it O
is O
anticipated O
that O
the O
historical O
operations O
of O
a O
specific O
venture O
may O
not O
necessarily O
be O
indicative O
of O
the O
potential O
for O
the O
future O
because O
of O
the O
necessity O
to O
substantially O
shift O
a O

approach O
" " O
expand O
operations O
" " O
change O
product O
emphasis O
" " O
change O
or O
substantially O
augment O
management O
" " O
or O
make O
other O
changes O
. O

The O
Company O
will O
be O
partially O
dependent O
upon O
the O
management O
of O
any O

business O
opportunity O
to O

and O
to O
implement O
" " O
or O

primarily O

for O
the O

required O

. O

Since O
we O
may O
participate O
in O
a O
business O
opportunity O
with O
a O
newly O
organized O
business O
or O
with O
a O

which O
is O
entering O

new O

of O
growth O
" " O

should O

that O

may O

of O

target O
’ O

to O
have O
proven O

" " O

the O

’ O

or O
services O
" " O

. O

The O

does O
not O

to O
acquire O
or O

with O
any O
company O
for O
which O
audited O

. O

Never-the-less O
" " O

that O

Our O

“ O

and I-GOVERNMENT

HARVESTING O
THE O
POTENTIAL O
IN O
OUR O
STATE O
. O

THE O
FINANCIAL O
SECTOR O
As O
alluded O
to O
earlier O
" " O
2009 O
witnessed O
the O
continuing O
of O
one O
of O
the O
most O
several O
global O
economic O
environments O
in O
decades O
. O

Michigan I-LOC
" " O
whose O
economy O
has O
been O
in O
recession O
for O
six O
years O
" " O
continued O
its O
roller O
coaster O
ride O
in O
virtually O
every O
economic O
sector O
. O

Two O
of O
our O
most O
storied O
corporations O
" " O
General I-ORG
Motors I-ORG
and O
Chrysler I-ORG
" " O
filed O
for O
bankruptcy O
. O

The O
failures O
in O
the O
financial O
sector O
" " O
primarily O
on O
Wall I-LOC
Street I-LOC
" " O
heightened O
the O
scrutiny O
of O
virtually O
every O
bank O
in O
the O
world O
. O

This O
scrutiny O
resulted O
in O
`` O
Main O
Street O
'' O
commercial O
banks O
being O
put O
in O
the O
same O
bucket O
as O
Wall I-LOC
Street I-LOC
investment O
banks O
. O

Banking O
regulators O
closed O
140 O
banks O
in O
2009 O
. O

This O
was O
the O
highest O
number O
of O
financial O
institution O
closures O
since O
the O
end O
of O
the O
savings O
and O
loan O
association O
crisis O
in O
1992 O
" " O
when O
181 O
FDIC-insured I-MISC
depository O
institutions O
failed O
. O

Of O
the O
140 O
institutions O
closed O
in O
2009 O
" " O
four O
were O
headquartered O
in O
Michigan I-LOC
. O

Many O
of O
our O
peers O
" " O
however O
" " O
continue O
to O
operate O
in O
a O
weakened O
position O
. O

Some O
have O
received O
funding O
from O
the O
U.S. I-GOVERNMENT
Treasury I-GOVERNMENT
's O
Troubled I-MISC
Asset I-MISC
Relief I-MISC
Program I-MISC
" " O
better O
known O
as O
TARP I-MISC
" " O
in O
order O
to O
shore O
up O
their O
capital O
levels O
. O

Because O
of O
our O
strong O
capital O
base O
" " O
Chemical I-ORG
Financial I-ORG
chose O
not O
to O
participate O
in O
the O
TARP I-MISC
program O
. O

Bank O
failures O
have O
increased O
the O
cost O
of O
doing O
business O
for O
all O
banks O
. O

The O
FDIC I-GOVERNMENT
" " O
whose O
insurance O
fund O
was O
depleted O
due O
to O
the O
cost O
of O
bank O
failures O
" " O
increased O
dramatically O
the O
premiums O
all O
remaining O
banks O
must O
pay O
. O

As O
mentioned O
earlier O
" " O
Chemical I-ORG
Bank I-ORG
had O
total O
assessed O
premiums O
of O
$ O
7.0 O
million O
in O
2009 O
" " O
compared O
to O
less O
than O
$ O
1 O
million O
in O
2008 O
. O

We O
and O
all O
other O
banks O
also O
prepaid O
a O
special O
three-year O
premium O
to O
the O
FDIC I-GOVERNMENT
for O
coverage O
from O
2010 O
to O
2012 O
" " O
which O
for O
us O
amounted O
to O
$ O
19.7 O
million O
. O

As O
often O
happens O
in O
distressed O
economic O
times O
" " O
a O
wave O
of O
regulatory O
and O
legislative O
`` O
solutions O
'' O
have O
surfaced O
. O

While O
the O
total O
impact O
of O
the O
myriad O
of O
regulatory O
and O
congressional O
proposals O
is O
unknown O
" " O
it O
is O
apparent O
that O
many O
of O
these O
so-called O
reforms O
are O
aimed O
at O
perpetrators O
of O
poor O
lending O
and O
investment O
practices O
. O

Unfortunately O
" " O
it O
will O
also O
affect O
those O
of O
us O
who O
never O
participated O
in O
such O
debacles O
. O

Chemical I-ORG
Financial I-ORG
avoided O
many O
problems O
that O
have O
manifested O
themselves O
in O
these O
reforms O
by O
not O
unduly O
leveraging O
our O
balance O
sheet O
" " O

maintaining O
high O
levels O
of O
liquidity O
" " O

avoiding O
esoteric O
financial O
investments O
and O
by O
not O

in O
the O
subprime O
mortgage O
market O
. O

Hopefully O
" " O

and O
representatives O
in O
Congress I-GOVERNMENT
will O
avoid O

every O
bank O
with O
the O

" " O
so O
that O
our O

are O
not O
adversely O

by O
over-reactionary O
decisions O
. O

About O
Epicor I-ORG
Software I-ORG
Corporation I-ORG
Epicor B-ORG
Software I-ORG
is O
a O
global O
leader O
delivering O
business O
software O
solutions O
to O

manufacturing O
" " O

" " O

" " O

services O

. O

With O
"20,000" O
customers O
in O
over O
150 O
countries O
" " O
Epicor I-ORG
provides O
integrated O

resource O

( O
ERP O
) O
" " O
customer O
relationship O
management O
( O
CRM O
) O
" " O
supply O
chain O
management O
( O
SCM O
) O
" " O
human O
capital O
management O
( O
HCM O
) O
and O
enterprise O
retail O
software O
solutions O
that O
enable O
companies O
to O
drive O
increased O
efficiency O
and O
improve O
profitability O
. O

Founded O
in O
1984 O
" " O
Epicor I-ORG
takes O
pride O
in O
more O
than O
25 O
years O
of O
technology O
innovation O
delivering O
business O
solutions O
that O
provide O
the O

and O
flexibility O
businesses O
need O
to O
build O
competitive O
advantage O
. O

Epicor I-ORG
